title: MAR files for Firefox Dev Edition
content:
I found this question from 5 years ago https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1097979 and it looks like the accepted answer still works today for normal releases of Firefox.

e.g. this URL works:

https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-91.0.2-partial-91.0.1&os=win&lang=en-US&force=1

However the URL format for Firefox Developer Edition doesn't seem to accept version strings, so I can't find MARs for devedition

e.g this URL works for devedition: https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-devedition-latest&os=linux64&lang=en-US

But these two don't (the second would be the pattern for a MAR): https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-devedition-92.0b8&os=linux64&lang=en-US https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-devedition-92.0b9-partial-92.0b8&os=linux64&lang=en-US

Presumably MAR files are available for devedition?

title: After smooth scrolling down a PDF, left clicking to stop smooth scrolling makes the PDF skip forward 5-15 pages
content:
I often read books etc in PDF form using the Mozilla reader, and I typically click the scroll wheel to enable smooth scrolling so I don't have to use the wheel to scroll down. However, after I have been doing this for at least a few minutes, there is an 80% or so chance of experiencing a problem. When I left click on the page to disable smooth scrolling, the PDF will flicker and instantly have skipped forward about 10 pages. If I use the right click or scroll wheel to disable smooth scrolling it won't happen, but then left clicking on the page makes it skip ahead the same way. It gets frustrating having to scroll back so frequently, especially if I forgot to note which page I will have to scroll back to

I've tried reinstalling Firefox etc but I can't think of what could be causing this issue and how to fix it as it doesn't seem to be addressed online anywhere

Would be grateful for some help!
creator: abbyjgibson

title: Browser search in the wrong place
content:

title: That 5 Billionth Search Scam
content:
Did a search and clicked https://foreverfuture.net/20x0mox/talking-heads-head-in-the-clouds

Somehow that's not where I went.

Instead the page opened with confetti and I didn't see the URL, but it said I had just conducted the 5 billionth search using Firefox! That seemed unlikely, so I immediately closed the tab.

Then I began to wonder. Had I perhaps actually conducted the 5 billionth search and did a non-profit like Mozilla want to make me wealthy?

So I logged into my Firefox account (had to reset the password). Nothing in my inbox.

Did a search and I am not alone!

I reran the search and clicked again. This time I can see the proper page and it's gibberish. Indexed by Google over a decade(!) ago. Time to report it and run some scans locally.

Fingers crossed.

title: ERROR :  "Hash not found" - with Firefox 91.0, 91.0.1 and 91.0.2.
content:
I always prefer to download updates myself, to then upload each to VirusTotal.com to see what the results are from the many scanners VT uses, before installing any software obtained from over the Internet. VT always begins the upload to the VT website by checking for a hash and this worked prior to Firefox 91.0.x, but has failed for all three updates since the last version before 91.0, so failing for 91.0, 91.0.1 and 91.0.2. The same thing also happens with Thunderbird 91.0.1 from Thunderbird.net, adding this note in case you can communicate regularly with the TBird team.

I'm glad to do the downloads, verifications and installs myself, for if anything ever goes wrong, then I have the downloaded installers to just re-install Ffx. But given that a hash isn't found for the downloaded 91.0.x updates, then I of course wonder what Mozilla is using when performing automatic updates. After all, what we download surely should be what Mozilla uses as well. So, I'll definitely stick to my preferred way of doing updates and definitely hope that this missing hash problem gets corrected very soon.

My current browser is still 90.0.2. It definitely is a "bit" buggy, flaky, often quite annoyingly so, but its hash was found and is still found by VT, so ....
